Ez_JZGpWcDHQjWpSWWxgvQ.text: If you want authentic, freshly made pasta, and want to feel like you've been transported into Italy for a little bit, then look no further. This place serves 6 appetizers, 10 types of pasta (mainly pappardelle and tagliatelle), and 2 desserts, so it's a fairly limited menu. They do have a decent amount of vegetarian options.This is located right by the London Bridge station, and close to Burrough Market, and you'll likely see a long queue outside the place around peak lunch and dinner hours. I came here around 2 pm on a Friday and didn't have to wait more than 10 minutes for a seat at the bar, but right after we were seated, the line grew to about 15-20 people. Be prepared to wait at least 15-30 minutes if you come (or more), and don't come with more than 2-3 people as you may be waiting forever for a table. Most the seating is at the bar, counter along the window, or small tables. Burrata (£5) & Bread (£2) - I didn't care for the burrata too much. It didn't seem to have too much flavor to me, and was creamy in the middle but there was too much of a hardened shell around the cheese. It was good with the olive oil and salt, but at times I felt like I was eating chunks of salt that wasn't well-distributed in the dish. I would stick to just the bread and olive oil next time.Pappardelle with 8-hour beef shin ragu (£8.5) - The noodles are were al dente and delicious, and the meat was tender and had been slow-cooked in the tomato sauce. The size of the pasta dishes are on the smaller side, and they do put a lot of parmesan cheese on top of some of the pastas -- so if you're lactose intolerant or don't like cheese, just beware.The service was a little bit on the slow side - I don't know why there was a 15-20 min wait from when we got the burrata to when we got the pastas, when everyone around us ordered after us and got their food before us. It was a little annoying and I didn't find the waiters particularly friendly.All in all though, a solid pasta joint that is still relatively quick from start to finish (after waiting in line), and worth a visit if you are craving Italian food. Just be prepared to wait in line and know that they don't take reservations! I'd come back here again but not sure if I would wait more than 30-45 min in line.

dJR37suD40lnhm6CmkNZyw.text: Perfection in the form of pasta - but if you don't have time to queue, a good alternative is La Tua which is further inside Borough Market.Padella and Trullo are undoubtedly my favourite Italian places in London. Like many many more, they have my blessing - although I don't know if they need anyone's blessing. Tim Sadatan is a success story and the more I have his food, every time I go, I admire him and his food philosophy even more.There is something very sexy and special about fresh pasta and the long queues that form quickly in front of Padella is proof of this.  If you have time, it's worth the wait.  Not too many ingredients go into each dish, but as many have said before, it's the perfect simplicity of the dishes that's the charm.  On my most recent visit, I resisted the temptation to get the Parpadelle with Beef Shin ragu (easily one of the best pastas in London) and go for the vegetarian option of the Tagliarini with Chiarentana Olive Oil and Parmesan which is a rare thing for me as I simply love meat. After the first bite, I said to myself, yes this is one of those dishes that could convert you into being a vegetarian.  It was simple but solid and delightful. Just Wow. So yes, it goes without saying that I'm a very big fan of Tim Sadatan.  However, the queues although they do move considerably quickly and guests are normally thoughtful and nice enough to have the common sense to not take too long so that other people in the queue can also have the delicious pasta, the wait could take as long as an hour or more.  If you are in a rush, especially if you're travelling and you don't have time to queue for Padella, La Tua Pasta which serves fresh raviolis is not a bad alternative to fall back on.  In fact, their raviolis are super delicious and is a couple of minutes walk away from Padella.  Or, if you must sample Tim Sadatan's dishes and you want certainty with timing, why not make a reservation at Trullo? You can sample the pastas there and also taste other non-pasta goodies.

5GIwh8fPAuhS8W3d90DUZQ.text: Grabbed a beer from a nearby vendor since I thought I would be queuing for an hour or so, but was pleasantly surprised to walk up to zero people waiting outside around 3:30pm on a Thursday. Sat right in the heart of the action at the bar that is perfectly situated in the assembly line of the kitchen.  Even though there was a lot of hustle and bustle around me, I felt like I had the whole place to myself in some strange way. Seeing as it's as fast-casual as you can be for Italian but still dons the affluence of a white tablecloth Italian restaurant, I was pleasantly surprised at the prices (very fair, even before factoring in the quality of the ingredients and presentation).I started with the burrata and bread and a glass of wine and both were a beautiful start to the meal. I wanted to inhale every last crumb of the bread basket, but tried to maintain some kind of decorum since I still had my entree on the horizon. If there's not a line and you're not terribly hungry, I'd recommend popping in for just that little amuse bouche. I had a hard time deciding between the 4-5 main pasta dishes but push came to shove and I went with their Pici Cacio & Pepe, as that is what brought me to this particular establishment in the first place. While not a hefty dish, it was the ideal amount of pasta given that the sauce is super decadent. I savored each bite and extended the meal into a two hour tour (given that they close from 4-5pm everyday so I wasn't handicapping the seat for another eager diner). I thoroughly enjoy a lot of pepper in my cacio & Pepe dishes, but appreciated the subtly of theirs given that they wanted to showcase the flavor profile of the sauce without having to lean on the flakes for good measure.Service was delightful and if I'm not mistaken, most of the front of house was Italian, making the experience even more authentic feeling.(In using the restroom, I happened upon a downstairs dining area, so the place is bigger than it lets on from the exterior).

Fresh ground peppercorns add nuance.   However, the pasta itself is the star. Perfectly cooked with al-dente texture. Smooth, dense and a pleasure to eat. No question that this is made by hand with love. If I'm in the area again I might return to try a different pasta dish.

8SGPV_EhJpqKvzk6TPtAXg.text: I arrived at 5:30PM on a Wednesday, stood in line for 15 min, got on the queue and a table was ready for 2 at 6:15PM, all in all a 45 minute wait, which is not bad.I have been here a couple times already, with my first time right around when it first opened. The handmade fresh pasta is delicious and they have a rotating menu. Price wise, it was between 7-12 GBP per plate, which is pretty good by London standards. The atmosphere is loud, and everyone is in a hurry to serve customers. Service was quick, can't say it is amazing but it certainly feels like a well oiled machine so that it is quick to turnover tables. For me, I probably won't return unless I had a visitor that insists on going. Although the wait for me this time wasn't so bad, I think it is pretty typical to wait at least 2 hours for a table. The restaurant is a bit to busy and loud. Although the pasta is delicious, there is another pasta place (close by) that I'd like to think serve the same quality of handmade pasta with a rotating menu, at a similar price point, and all without the extreme wait in a little more intimate setting.

h-dGmgbcrOW-H0ytVV97xw.text: My boyfriend and I were walking around London when we saw a huge line for Padella. This piqued our curiosity, so we decided to check it out for lunch the following day. We went for a late lunch, not too long before they closed and the place was still packed. Despite being the only ones in line, we still had a bit of a wait and were nearly turned away. However, we lucked out and were able to snag a spot at the bar. We ordered the beef shin ragù, as we read many rave reviews about it, and we also selected the fettuccine with tomatoes, garlic & basil. Both were absolutely wonderful and on par with the pasta we had all throughout Italy in the past. The best part was that it was pretty inexpensive for a meal in London. Don't let the line at Padella intimidate you. It is well worth the wait!

gljWkT5ZXZDQZ7oR7MtUwA.text: Absolutely worth the wait! I heard about this place from watching a YouTube clip about foods in borough market so I had to try it myself. There was a queue on a Friday afternoon, but I got a table with a friend within 30-45 min. The place is pretty small, but if you're lucky you can sit at the counter where you can watch the pasta dishes being cooked. There were about 5-6 different types of pasta dishes ranging from gnocchi to linguini with mussels. The pasta dishes ranged from £4.50-10.50.My friend and I ordered 3 pasta dishes- gnocchi with basic cream sauce, linguini with baby mussels and this thick pasta in a beef ragout. The pasta dishes were all AMAZING! The sauce of the gnocchi wasn't overwhelming and the pasta was soft tender pillows. The linguini dish had a light sauce flavoured by the mussels and had no fishy after taste. The thick pasta with the beef ragout was absolutely amazing. The sauce was thick and rich from the meat stock. Overall this place delivered and met my expectations. The price was decent and the flavours were amazing!

f8oem4Muejsm8RaOPS8mRg.text: Both times I tried to come here, they said the restaurant was full and that there were no available tables so I was really glad that on the third try I was able to finally get a table - you have to come pretty early and wait in line (at least 440pm for the 5pm dinner). All of the food here is extremely good, quick and cheap. We were shocked by the prices, after having eaten out at a lot of other places in Europe.For antipasti, we ordered the Crostini, the Burrata and the sourdough bread with the oil (which is a must with the burrata because you don't get any bread with the burrata). The crostini was something else - the ricotta cheese was extremely flavorful and rich and the tomatoes added a nice touch. The bread wasn't too hard as well. The burrata and bread were also extremely good, although it doesn't have the same strong taste as the Crostini. Definitely make sure to mix some oil on each bite of bread you take. For the main course, I ordered the Pici dish and really enjoyed it. The sauce is a bit salty but has great texture and is just the right amount of creamy. The pasta is also very well cooked and has a soft texture and goes great with the sauce. I also ordered the Pear Spritz drink which was extremely refreshing. It has a little bitterness to it, but it is well carbonated and sweet. The slice of grapefruit at the end is also a nice touch. For dessert, we split the chocolate sorbet and it was heavenly. It is like rich dark chocolate ice cream that is not as bitter as you would expect. It was honestly too much food at that point, but still well worth it. Considering the price, this is easily one of the best pasta places I've been to.

etlU3MMPoi9Z_31zfX3PKg.text: I went here 4 times in the 8 days I was in London. We went here for the first time right after we landed at Gatwick. 0DI5LJBOTxnbiLhtRTLi4w.text: So I have seen a lot of recent reviews about this place. It is obviously the new kid on the block to a certain degree, so all reviewers and bloggers are getting involved. As I am a regular in London bridge, I had passed this place a lot and never got the opportunity to go in as I was put off by the queues. So Lobos nearby took got cash. Finally we decided that we need to bite the bullet and see what all of the fuss is about. We settled in the queue on a Wednesday after a drink at the lovely Globe Tavern nearby. We queued for one hour and 10 minutes. At no point did anyone come out, work the queue, acknowledge us, write a name on a clip board, walk by with some tasters, nowt. You just stood in that queue having no inclination as to how long this would become your temporary home. I have worked in the service industry, so I disagree that this should be the norm. You could walk up, take names and party numbers. Even if you had no intention of closely monitoring the activity inside to see how soon a table would become free, its a psychological thing. It gives people the impression that there is light at the end of the tunnel. That simple interaction. I think I, like others, had bought into the current buzz that surrounds this place, so against my better nature, there I was, in a queue. When we were finally seated inside, we are guided to a basement. Outside you don't know there is additional space. We at at the bar in a cramped corner, but were delighted to start our food journey. The menu is small and simple. In the queue we could hear those who felt like Padella experts discuss the menu and the dishes, what dishes you MUST have, scrolling through various instagram, google and twitter images. We wanted to take a leap of faith and just grab what we fancied. The service was OK. It was rushed. Not rude, but certainly not warm. We ordered two glasses of prosecco from the bartender a mulled over our dinner options to his disdain. I just didn't immediately get it. This was his opportunity to say, hey, what don't you guys get that, partner it with this and have a hit of that. He worked there, he knew the menu, he could have helped. Instead, he leaned over the bar to us, arms on the surface, waiting for us to order so he could move on to slicing bread, making drinks and serving up desserts. We both went for the buratta as this seems to be my "must have". Maybe I should just start a buratta blog as I am intrigued by this dish and how many variation there are of it (stingy to plentiful - Padella was midway). For main we went for spaghetti with tomato sauce and also fettuccine with chilli (nduja). With a side of sourdough bread, we expected to be full up. I think our naivety on the menu showed as our choices were not the best. I am not sure we got the full effect of Padella. To be frank, the food was just okay. Whilst Lobos blew our mind with their Spanish tapas, Italian landed with a wet thud. I know there is a connection to this place to another joint which is apparently good in Islingon, but I like to judge things on their own, individual merits.  Following little interaction with the team, we paid up our bill and left feeling a little deflated. Our one hour plus wait had produced a 35 minute mediocre dining experience.

56FbCSEYMRDOwvi25FMigQ.text: I came here with three friends last night, looking for a cheap dinner and a good catch up, and as we are all good friends, it wasn't awkward to queue for the 30 or so minutes that it takes to get a table. I was surprised by how good the location is - it is literally right by the tube station and Borough Market - and you can't miss the queue. Once inside, initially we were offered four seats by the window on the ground floor, but my friend who had been to the restaurant before insisted that we wait for one of the tables downstairs, where you can actually get a table and have proper conversation. Upstairs it is mostly bar seating, so more ideal for 2 people than for larger groups. Also, once downstairs, you don't feel the pressure of having the entire queue watch you through the window. The one thing I found very strange is that either they are not very good at efficiently filling tables, or they are purposely keeping tables empty downstairs so that they keep a long queue outside (much like a club). The entire bar downstairs was empty when we came in, and while we were dining there were at least 2 other tables that were vacated and left empty. On the other hand, service was excellent, so it is possible that they were just understaffed and didn't want to seat more people than they could properly serve, but then again that would be another problem they should solve.The menu is pleasantly simple with about 6 choices of antipasti and another 6 choices of pasta. My friend who had dined here previously said the antipasti was rather missable, so we went ahead and ordered 6 pastas. Service was really quick, and they were all brought to the table at the same time. There was a special with girolle mushrooms, and on top of that we got a tagliarini with raw courgette and prawns, the ricotta ravioli with sage butter, the pappardelle with beef shin ragu, the pici cacao e pepe, and the tagliatelle with nduja and parsley. Of those, my favourite was the one with girolle mushrooms and the beef shin ragu. The tagliatelle with nduja was far too spicy for my enjoyment. The other one that was a little underwhelming was the tagliarini with raw courgette and prawns - the prawns were no bigger than the size of your nail and the dish was light and lacked flavour. For dessert, we shared both the almond / rhubarb and chocolate tart, which were both delicious. We also enjoyed the merlot from Vini Stocco, which for the 500ml size basically made for four glasses, so we got two. It was decent, but I wouldn't be in a rush to have it again. After our meal, we lingered a while longer, and the staff was in no hurry to get us to leave, despite the sizeable queue still outside. I'm kind of convinced this is just a huge marketing ploy. I would recommend people go to Trullo, where you can have the exact same dishes in a nice setting without the queue.
